0_Atelectasis: A chest X-ray showing focal volume loss with increased radiopacity in the affected lung.
Radiograph demonstrating a shift of the pulmonary fissures toward the area of collapse.
Image indicative of atelectasis showing elevation of the hemidiaphragm on the ipsilateral side.
Frontal view displaying mediastinal or tracheal deviation toward the collapsed lung segment.
X-ray feature presenting a triangular or wedge-shaped density pointing towards the hilum.
1_Cardiomegaly: A chest X-ray revealing a significantly enlarged transverse cardiac diameter.
Frontal radiograph showing a cardiothoracic ratio greater than 0.5 indicative of cardiomegaly.
Image demonstrating bilateral or unilateral expansion of the cardiac silhouette.
Lateral view displaying the posterior cardiac border projecting backward beyond the spine.
Radiographic appearance where the cardiac apex is rounded or displaced downward and laterally.
2_Effusion: A chest X-ray showing blunting or complete obliteration of the costophrenic angle.
Radiograph demonstrating homogeneous opacity obscuring the lower lung field.
Image featuring a meniscus sign with a concave upper border suggestive of fluid.
Frontal view showing a massive opacity causing mediastinal shift away from the affected side.
X-ray display of widened intercostal spaces associated with fluid accumulation.
3_Infiltration: A chest X-ray displaying ill-defined patchy or cloudy opacities within the lung fields.
Radiograph demonstrating heterogeneous density representing interstitial or alveolar exudate.
Image showing opacities that do not completely obscure the underlying vascular markings.
Frontal view revealing a localized segmental or diffuse bilateral distribution of infiltrates.
X-ray feature consistent with early inflammatory changes or interstitial lung disease.
4_Mass: A chest X-ray identifying a focal soft tissue density larger than 3 centimeters in diameter.
Radiograph showing a lesion with margins that may be smooth, lobulated, or irregular.
Image demonstrating a homogeneous density potentially containing central cavitation or calcification.
Frontal view showing signs of compression on surrounding tissues causing secondary atelectasis.
X-ray feature of a distinct space-occupying lesion requiring comparison with prior imaging.
5_Nodule: A chest X-ray showing a round or oval opacity smaller than 3 centimeters in diameter.
Radiograph demonstrating a solitary lesion or multiple scattered dense spots.
Image featuring a benign-appearing nodule with smooth edges and central calcification.
Frontal view revealing a nodule with malignant features such as spiculation or pleural tagging.
X-ray display of a focal density ranging from ground-glass opacity to solid consolidation.
6_Pneumonia: A chest X-ray exhibiting patchy consolidation within a lobar or segmental distribution.
Radiograph demonstrating increased focal density with ill-defined and blurry margins.
Image showing characteristic air bronchograms visible within the opacified area.
Frontal view displaying an asymmetrical area of inflammation distinct from surrounding lung.
X-ray feature showing non-homogeneous shadows indicative of acute infection.
7_Pneumothorax: A chest X-ray showing a peripheral hyperlucent area devoid of pulmonary vascular markings.
Radiograph demonstrating a visible thin white line representing the visceral pleura.
Image featuring compression and retraction of the lung parenchyma toward the hilum.
Frontal view indicative of tension pneumothorax showing mediastinal shift to the contralateral side.
X-ray display of a deep sulcus sign or increased lucency in the hemithorax.
8_Consolidation: A chest X-ray showing airspace opacification where air is replaced by fluid or cells.
Radiograph demonstrating obscuration of pulmonary vessels within a dense white area.
Image featuring clear air bronchograms showing patent airways against a solid background.
Frontal view displaying blurry margins unless the process is bounded by a pleural fissure.
X-ray feature typical of lobar pneumonia involving complete alveolar filling.
9_Edema: A chest X-ray revealing increased, thickened, and blurry pulmonary vascular markings.
Radiograph demonstrating Kerley B lines appearing as horizontal lines near the costophrenic angles.
Image showing a central bat-wing or butterfly pattern of perihilar opacity.
Frontal view displaying bilateral symmetrical densities favoring gravity-dependent zones.
X-ray feature associated with cardiomegaly and a widened vascular pedicle.
10_Emphysema: A chest X-ray showing hyperinflation with significantly increased radiolucency of the lungs.
Radiograph demonstrating flattening of the hemidiaphragms and blunting of costophrenic angles.
Image featuring a widened retrosternal space and barrel chest appearance on lateral view.
Frontal view displaying a narrow, vertical heart shadow often described as a drop heart.
X-ray display of bullae appearing as avascular thin-walled lucent areas.
11_Fibrosis: A chest X-ray exhibiting diffuse or focal reticular or linear interstitial markings.
Radiograph demonstrating volume loss accompanied by traction bronchiectasis.
Image featuring coarse reticulation or honeycomb changes indicative of advanced disease.
Frontal view showing sharp margins that are distinct from the surrounding normal lung.
X-ray feature presenting distortion or displacement of the hilar structures and diaphragm.
12_PleuralThickening: A chest X-ray showing a band-like soft tissue density running along the lateral chest wall.
Radiograph demonstrating blunted costophrenic angles that do not shift with position change.
Image featuring irregular plaque-like calcifications along the pleural surface.
Frontal view indicative of scarring with associated volume loss and rib crowding.
X-ray display of pleural changes often sequelae of prior inflammation or trauma.
13_Hernia: A chest X-ray showing a retrocardiac or mediastinal mass containing air pockets.
Radiograph demonstrating the presence of an air-fluid level within the thoracic cavity.
Image featuring mild contralateral mediastinal shift due to the mass effect of herniated viscera.
Frontal view displaying disruption or obscuration of the normal hemidiaphragm contour.
X-ray feature confirming gastric bubble or bowel loops located above the diaphragm level.
